article.title: Preparing the way for medical emergency drones
article.teaser: New training courses and a comprehensive Guidebook can help cities and regions to prepare for the roll-out of medical emergency drones.

section.sectionBody:
The delivery of emergency medical services (EMSs) via air could revolutionise healthcare in urban areas. Potential applications include the delivery of defibrillators in response to out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, blood in response to disaster situations, and rapid assistance in rescue operations.
Before medical urban air mobility (UAM) operations can be rolled out however, certain challenges still need to be addressed.
“These challenges are not really about the technology itself, which is moving forward at an ultra-fast pace,” explains https://airmour.eu/ (AiRMOUR) project coordinator Petri Mononen from the https://www.vttresearch.com/en (VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland).
“Instead, the challenges are really about knowledge levels, and the preparedness of cities and regions to manage aviation within urban airspaces.”

A key aim of the EU-funded AiRMOUR project was therefore to encourage cities and regional authorities to start preparing for UAM operations.
“When it comes to aviation, cities have typically only been concerned about access to airports,” says Mononen. “Now suddenly they need to think about dealing with the urban airspace itself.”
The AiRMOUR project focused on emergency and medical services delivered by https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/861111 (drone), a likely trailblazer in emerging UAM services. To begin with, likely UAM EMS scenarios, such as rescue services, were identified. These were then validated through live flights.
Key issues assessed during these tests included potential air and ground risks and cyber security, as well as citizen acceptance, and the legal framework needed to ensure responsible operations. Business models and carbon dioxide life-cycle analyses were also carried out, to assess the sustainability of the concept.

section.sectionTitle: Insights into using drones in cities
section.sectionBody:
From the information gathered during these trials, the project team developed a UAM https://airmour.eu/deliverables/ (training curriculum), complete with online courses and masterclasses. These courses were designed to provide stakeholders – such as emergency services and logistics operators – with insights into the use of medical drones in urban areas.
A https://airmour.eu/deliverables/ (project Guidebook) has also been made available in seven different languages. This covers everything from use cases and the scalability of operations, through to public perceptions.
“The wide uptake of our recommendations – whether at the city level or EU authority level – is a clear indicator of the real-life impact and success of the project,” remarks Mononen.
“I am extremely happy to see that AiRMOUR has already contributed to the emergence of several new related research initiatives in the partnering Member States and beyond. This is a success in itself.”

The project consortium is now looking to ensure that as many stakeholders as possible start proactively preparing for UAM EMSs. “It is largely up to cities, regions and EMS-responsible organisations to take action,” says Mononen.
“We think that the best way to start is to pick up our UAM Guidebook, and carry on from there.”
Mononen believes that in this way, the AiRMOUR project represents a major milestone in setting UAM in motion in Europe. He hopes that the key results – the training package and Guidebook – will become staple documents that are periodically updated to reflect technological and regulatory advances.
“The project has also been integral in identifying key research areas that will now need to be further developed,” he adds.

article.keywords: AiRMOUR, medical, urban, drone, emergency, UAM, EMS, aviation

article.title: Placing ethics at the heart of emerging technologies
article.teaser: New methods and tools have been developed to ensure that ethics and human rights are fully considered in the roll-out of key cutting-edge technologies.

section.sectionBody:
https://builtin.com/artificial-intelligence (Artificial intelligence) (AI), https://humgenomics.biomedcentral.com/ (human genomics) and https://www.sienna-project.eu/enhancement/ (human enhancement) are likely to have major economic and social impacts in the near future. At the same time, these emerging technologies raise serious ethical, legal and human rights issues.
“The objective of the https://www.sienna-project.eu/ (SIENNA) project was to study these issues, and to propose ways of addressing them,” explains project coordinator Philip Brey, professor of Philosophy of Technology at the https://www.utwente.nl/en/ (University of Twente) in the Netherlands.

AI includes systems that support human decision-making, are able to analyse large data sets and can recognise faces and behaviours. It also includes machines like intelligent robots and self-driving cars.
“AI can autonomously make decisions and perform actions in ways that were previously reserved for human beings,” says Brey. “But this means that it can also do all the bad things that humans can do. It can control people, discriminate and violate privacy, for example. Who is accountable if intelligent machines do bad things?”
Human genomics is a powerful technology that could improve human health. “Yet there are important ethical implications here too,” he notes. "For example, https://www.genome.gov/about-genomics/fact-sheets/DNA-Sequencing-Fact-Sheet (Genome sequencing) can raise significant privacy issues, as third parties become aware of one’s detailed genetic make-up. This information could be used to discriminate against employees or insurance policyholders.”
Finally, human enhancement is about the improvement of human performance beyond the typical range. Such enhancements might include superior eyes and ears, or legs and arms with improved strength and endurance.
“Many people think the very idea is wrong,” says Brey. “In any case, there are health and safety risks, and concerns about loss of human identity and inequality.”

The EU-supported SIENNA project set out to identify and analyse the ethical and human rights issues connected with these three technologies. It then sought to develop tools and methods to help stakeholders better address and mitigate these concerns.
“We wanted to map out current issues as well as challenges that could be expected over the next 20 years,” explains Brey. “We also wanted to know about the concerns and viewpoints of stakeholders.”
To achieve this, hundreds of stakeholders were consulted, and some 11 000 citizens surveyed across 11 countries. Extensive legal analysis was carried out to understand the current regulatory landscape.
“Based on our understanding of these issues, we developed proposals and solutions,” adds Brey. “We also drew up ethics guidelines. This was particularly needed for human enhancement, as no guidelines existed.” Regulatory and policy recommendations concerning these three technology fields were also put forward.
For human genomics, an international code of conduct for data sharing was developed. Recommendations for including ethical and human rights requirements in legislation and regulation were drawn up. An https://interestingengineering.com/ethics-by-design-steps-for-the-responsible-use-of-technology (Ethics by Design) approach for AI was also put forward.
“There has already been take-up of our analyses and recommendations,” he remarks. “The European Commission will use our research ethics guidelines for AI and human enhancement, and our Ethics by Design approach in its ethics review procedure in the new https://ec.europa.eu/info/horizon-europe_en (Horizon Europe) research programme. This means that potentially hundreds of new research projects will make use of our tools and insights.”
Ultimately, SIENNA has highlighted the fact that ethics and human rights must be central considerations in the development and use of emerging technologies, and not afterthoughts.
“General ethical guidelines can be an important first step for creating awareness of ethical issues,” says Brey. “But they need to be supplemented with specific tools and methods, like research ethics frameworks, professional ethics codes and Ethics by Design approaches.”
This has been the project’s critical contribution, as Europe stands on the threshold of a new era in technological innovation

article.keywords: SIENNA, AI, genomics, technologies, robots, ethics, health, human, intelligent

article.title: Another small step: A new age of solar system exploration
article.teaser: Whilst the dominant scientific concern at the beginning of the new decade has been the very much rooted-on-Earth pandemic, excitement and renewed commitment to space exploration may see the 2020s eventually remembered for a surge of reignited interest in the Final Frontier. A new global space race is under way between the world’s major powers to be the first to unearth new secrets about our immediate celestial neighbourhood, the solar system.

article.title: Applying circularity to car electronics
article.teaser: Technological solutions and digital tools improve recovery of critical raw materials from electronic car parts along the automotive industry value chain.

section.sectionBody:
Older cars are made of metal, glass and plastic, and automotive recycling facilities are designed to recover these materials. However, newer cars include essential electronic components, and the metals making up these components are not adequately recycled.
The EU-funded https://www.treasureproject.eu/ (TREASURE) project developed an online platform as well as multiple reconfigured recycling units to help recover the metals used in modern car electronics.

section.sectionTitle: Initiative to recover critical raw materials
section.sectionBody:
The supply of https://single-market-economy.ec.europa.eu/sectors/raw-materials/areas-specific-interest/critical-raw-materials_en (critical raw materials (CRMs)) is essential to multiple industries and a Europe-wide concern. CRMs are essential to reaching Green Deal goals, therefore, recovering rare metals through recycling is critical to improving the EU’s supply of CRMs.
Barriers to implementing circular economy (CE) practices go beyond the lack of properly equipped recycling facilities. The project envisions a future in which the end-of-life (EoL) recovery of materials is built into the design of new cars, but the lack of communication between various actors is a challenge. Proprietary market concerns hinder cooperation between car manufacturers and car part suppliers, and relevant regulations – both existing and those under development – need to be clearer to stakeholders.
TREASURE reduced barriers in several ways. An advisory framework connects disassembly, recycling and design actors, and the project created a policy guideline to provide industry players and politicians with needed information. TREASURE also created the first in-depth assessment of car electronics lifecycle and circularity. A digital platform composed of a four-module toolbox that uses an AI-based scenario assessment tool to compare different perspectives on disassembly processes, recyclability and circularity performance is a major achievement.
The automotive industry has responded well to the resources provided by TREASURE, and the platform is seen as the first step in enabling secure information exchange in EoL activities.

Digital tools are critical to improving automotive CE, but the EoL recovery of CRMs requires new recycling operations as well. TREASURE built on earlier EU-funded projects to reconfigure a hydrometallurgical processing plant for recovery of precious, critical and base metals. According to project coordinator Paolo Rosa: “The modular hydrometallurgical plant developed in TREASURE is a process fully dedicated to the recovery of precious metals from both obsolete car electronics, LCDs (liquid crystal display) and IME (in-mould electronics) parts. Specifically, the recovered silver has been reused to produce new IME parts.”
Another reconfigured process developed by TREASURE involves the deconstruction of PCBs (printed circuit boards). Rosa states: “AI and robotics have been adopted to develop a semi-automated PCB disassembly process dedicated to the recognition of electronic components present on obsolete PCBs and their subsequent desoldering. This improves the recovery rate of materials for the subsequent hydrometallurgical process.”
With a consortium consisting of 15 partners across seven EU countries, TREASURE addressed a complex problem with a multifaceted approach. The project produced digital resources to support communication and recovery of CRMs along the automotive industry value chain. It also built on technological solutions to improve recycling so that CRMs can be reused in manufacturing electronic car parts, avoiding downcycling of degraded materials. In these ways, TREASURE is steering car manufacturing towards fuller CE participation.

article.keywords: TREASURE, recycling, critical raw materials, circularity, car electronics, PCB disassembly, hydrometallurgical processing, green in-mould electronics, digital platform

result.title: Barriers and Solutions for Information Exchange and Decision Performance
result.description: Linked to T23 Provides the Barriers and Solutions for Information Exchange and Decision Performance for the CircThread projects including as outcomes an understanding of why the information exchanges as identified in the Circthread use cases between actors are currently not carried out from economicsocialorganisational aspects the barriers an understanding of the needs of stakeholders regarding trust security and data sovereignty for all the product information aspects and a mapping of solutions to remove the barriers from IT process and organisational perspectivesThe deliverable will include based on the user needs identified for circular economy and barriers and potential solutions in relation to the use cases an evaluation with recommendations on policy issues for a Circular Economy in Europe and is marked as contributing to policy issuesrecommendations

result.title: Pilots Deployment And Testing Plan
result.description: Linked to T7.1 Provides the Pilots Deployment and testing plan for the CircThread projects including as outcomes: a detailed deployment plan for each of the three pilots including which services will be used when and by whom for what purposes and at what time, the management structure of each of the pilots with responsibilities with risks and contingencies and mitigation steps, and a deployment plan in terms of the planning steps, procurement needs and communications for tests to be carried out, and an overview of the testing procedures and KPIs to be provided from each tests for benchmarking. Finally it will include the performance monitoring & evaluation framework for monitoring, feedback, evaluation and adaptation of the plan, and a description of the helpdesk that is setup during the task for debugging.

result.title: User Centred Design & Deployment Requirements
result.description: Linked to T24 Provides the User Centred Design Deployment Requirements for the CircThread projects including as outcomes an understanding of the options for the deployment of a CircThread instance actors process and setup needs and model of collaboration and permission policies with an understanding of the minimum requirements to setup a CircThread instance It will also as outcome lead to an understanding of the user centred design requirements for CircThread on who would likely be involved in the various organisations in using the platform the skills they would need to use it personal motivations for using the system and information awareness needs

result.title: Use Case Information Requirements Evaluation
result.description: Linked to T22 Provides the Use Case Information Requirements Evaluation for the CircThread projects including as outcomes an indepth evaluation of the seven CircThread circular economy product use cases with the consortium for the home appliance and home energy sectors including evaluations of use case variants for construction electronic products and packaging sectors The evaluation will include the results of stakeholder workshops and interviews with translation of their needs into concrete user story formats As an actor I want to obtain X information for Y decision in format Z and linkages to the services required for execution of each use case in terms of information needs at each product life cycle point with a first scoping of the IT landscape for CircThread that will feed into T51 on the architecture A final outcome is a requirements analysis for sector level aggregation and linkages to the EU RMIS

result.title: Meta-Data Catalogue Service Overview and Technical Description
result.description: Linked to T4.6 Provides the Meta-Data Catalogue Service Overview and Technical Description for the CircThread projects including as outcomes: an overview of the finalised meta-data-catalogue service based on the refinement of D4.1 works, a description of the user facing side of the configurator in terms of funtionality including the user structure and features needed with the user interface design and frontend-backend linkages, it will also describe the linkage between the user provided informations and the catalogue information in related to the Digital Product Memory, and provide an overview of the deployment of the service and tested user scenarios.
